German firm drops Falls as site for 1,000 new jobs 
 
 By SHARON LINSTEDT
 News Staff Reporter
 1/20/2006
 
 <http://www.buffalonews.com<
 
A German chemical company, which was considering Western New York for a $620 million project that would have brought 1,000 new jobs to the region, is looking elsewhere after failing to obtain guarantees on cheap hydropower.
 
 Munich-based Wacker Chemie AG, which had put a 300-acre site in Niagara County on its short list for development of a new U.S. manufacturing facility, walked away from the negotiating table last week over the power issue, according to Thomas A. Kucharski, president of Buffalo Niagara Enterprise.
 
 "They needed a guarantee that they would be able to get 70 megawatts of low-cost power by 2009, and we couldn't find anyone in New York State that could provide that commitment," Kucharski said. "It's just mind-boggling and very frustrating."
 
 The BNE had hoped to offer Wacker a block of low-cost power at a rate just over 3 cents per kilowatt as part of an incentive package. That would be a dramatic savings over the typical cost range of 11 to 16 cents per kilowatt.
 
 Wacker was able to obtain written commitments for cheap power from the four other locales on its short list, a list believed to include one site in Canada and three in the southeastern United States.
 
 Buffalo Niagara Partnership President Andrew J. Rudnick echoed Kucharski's frustration when he went public on the Wacker situation Thursday as part of an update on the 5-year-old "Buffalo Niagara Now!" business development initiative.
 
 "This was an extraordinary situation that required an extraordinary response, and we couldn't give it," Rudnick said of the behind-the-scenes effort to lure Wacker to Western New York.
 
 Rudnick said local economic development executives were in contact with the New York State Power Authority, Gov. George E. Pataki's office, the Empire State Development Corp., as well as state and federal lawmakers, but could not secure a formal guarantee on a power allocation for the project.
 
 "We knew going in that this was a big ask, a huge amount of power, but the bottom line is we couldn't find someone to say "yes' or "no.' This was a major economic opportunity, and we were left hanging," Rudnick said.
 
 Brian Vittamo, the Power Authority's senior vice president for public and governmental affairs, disputes charges the Authority dropped the ball. "We committed to 37 megawatts right now and made it clear the company could apply for more down the road. I'm sure this was put down in writing," Vittamo said.
 
 Vittamo also said Empire State Development was the lead agency on wooing Wacker, an effort that had been given the code name "Project Bond." Representatives of the state development office declined to comment.
 
 A source familiar with efforts to attract Wacker to Niagara Falls said the state was prepared to offer the company an incentive package totaling more than $200 million, in addition to the power promise.
 
 Wacker is said to have shown strong interest in a 75-acre industrial site in the City of Niagara Falls, at the corner of 47th Street and Niagara Falls Boulevard. The parcel is adjacent to existing Praxair and Niacet operations, and is part of a 300-acre brownfields site.
 
 The family-owned German company has major facilities in Oregon and Michigan, as well as smaller manufacturing, sales and technical sites in California, Ohio, South Carolina, Kentucky and Iowa.
 
 Bill Toth, corporate spokesman for Wacker's U.S. division, declined to comment on the company's search for a new plant site. He said Wacker has not released any information regarding U.S. expansion plans.
 
 The 85-year-old company, which supplies silicon to the personal computer, telecommunications and electronics industry, has been rumored to be preparing for an initial public offering as early as this March in a bid to raise fresh capital. Wacker had earlier contemplated an IPO of its Siltronic unit, a maker of silicon wafers, to fund a major expansion of that business.
 
 Local development officials would not provide specific details on what type of plant Wacker plans to build, or how it would be financed. They expect Wacker to announce its expansion plans and the selected site late next month.
